items.content: The first international study to focus just on general practice has found patient violence and abuse is common, but interventions are under-researched.

ai_summary: The first international study focused on general practice found patient abuse is common.
The study revealed that violence and abuse towards staff is widespread in general practice.
Interventions to address this abuse are currently under-researched and not well-developed.
The study highlights the need for more research into effective interventions.
The findings underscore the challenges faced by general practice staff globally.

The news has brought emotional relief to doctors and patients alike.

clusters.title: Royal Parks say no evidence to back Nigel Farage’s claim that migrants are eating their swans – UK politics live
clusters.neutral_headline: Royal Parks deny Farage's swan eating claim

items.title: Royal Parks say no evidence to back Nigel Farage’s claim that migrants are eating their swans – UK politics live
items.standfirst: Reform UK leader claimed swans and carp being eaten from parks by ‘people from different cultures’The Royal Parks have rejected a claim from Nigel Farage that migrants are killing and eating swans from their grounds.The Reform UK leader made the assertion in his LBC interview this morning as he deflected a question about whether Donald Trump was wrong last year when he claimed migrants in Ohio were eating dogs and cats. Trump’s comment was widely dismissed as a racist slur.If I said to you that swans were being eaten in royal parks and carps were being taken out of ponds and eaten in this country from people with different cultures. Would you agree that is happening?We’ve not had any incidents reported to us of people killing or eating swans in London’s eight Royal Parks.Our wildlife officers work closely with the Swan Sanctuary to ensure the welfare of the swans across the parks. Continue reading...
items.content: Reform UK leader claimed swans and carp being eaten from parks by ‘people from different cultures’The Royal Parks have rejected a claim from Nigel Farage that migrants are killing and eating swans from their grounds.The Reform UK leader made the assertion in his LBC interview this morning as he deflected a question about whether Donald Trump was wrong last year when he claimed migrants in Ohio were eating dogs and cats. Trump’s comment was widely dismissed as a racist slur.If I said to you that swans were being eaten in royal parks and carps were being taken out of ponds and eaten in this country from people with different cultures. Would you agree that is happening?We’ve not had any incidents reported to us of people killing or eating swans in London’s eight Royal Parks.Our wildlife officers work closely with the Swan Sanctuary to ensure the welfare of the swans across the parks. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Nigel Farage claimed migrants are eating swans and carp in Royal Parks.
The Royal Parks stated they have no reports of swan or carp consumption.
Farage made the claim in an interview, deflecting a question about Trump.
Trump previously claimed migrants in Ohio ate dogs and cats.
The Royal Parks work with the Swan Sanctuary to ensure swan welfare.

clusters.title: Trump’s Tylenol announcement incurs furious backlash: ‘This is yet more utter rubbish’
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump's Tylenol announcement sparks backlash

items.title: Trump’s Tylenol announcement incurs furious backlash: ‘This is yet more utter rubbish’
items.standfirst: Medical professionals, pregnant people and those caring for people with autism note guidance’s disconnect from realityMedical professionals, pregnant people and readers with a relationship to autism are furious about Monday’s announcement from the Trump administration involving Tylenol and its alleged connection to autism.Within hours of the Guardian publishing a call for responses to the announcement, hundreds sent in their thoughts. Many of these individuals noted that the announcement had fascist undertones and was largely disconnected from the realities of science and the experience of being pregnant. A number of respondents suggested that this announcement was a bad-faith ploy to distract voters from issues that Trump wants removed from the discourse. Continue reading...
items.content: Medical professionals, pregnant people and those caring for people with autism note guidance’s disconnect from realityMedical professionals, pregnant people and readers with a relationship to autism are furious about Monday’s announcement from the Trump administration involving Tylenol and its alleged connection to autism.Within hours of the Guardian publishing a call for responses to the announcement, hundreds sent in their thoughts. Many of these individuals noted that the announcement had fascist undertones and was largely disconnected from the realities of science and the experience of being pregnant. A number of respondents suggested that this announcement was a bad-faith ploy to distract voters from issues that Trump wants removed from the discourse. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Medical professionals and others are furious about Trump's Tylenol announcement.
Critics note the announcement's disconnect from scientific realities.
Many respondents suggest the announcement has fascist undertones.
Some believe the announcement is a distraction from other issues.
The announcement involves a controversial link to autism.

items.title: Farage refuses to criticise Trump over paracetamol despite health experts dismissing autism claims
items.standfirst: Reform UK leader says he has ‘no idea’ if US president is right to tell women to avoid drug during pregnancyUK politics live – latest updatesNigel Farage has refused to criticise Donald Trump’s claims that paracetamol, sold in the US as Tylenol, could cause autism, insisting “science is never settled” and he would never “side with” medical experts.The Reform UK leader said he had “no idea” if the US president was right to tell pregnant women to avoid taking acetaminophen, also known as Tylenol and paracetamol, and suggesting that those who could not “tough it out” should limit their intake. Continue reading...
items.content: Reform UK leader says he has ‘no idea’ if US president is right to tell women to avoid drug during pregnancyUK politics live – latest updatesNigel Farage has refused to criticise Donald Trump’s claims that paracetamol, sold in the US as Tylenol, could cause autism, insisting “science is never settled” and he would never “side with” medical experts.The Reform UK leader said he had “no idea” if the US president was right to tell pregnant women to avoid taking acetaminophen, also known as Tylenol and paracetamol, and suggesting that those who could not “tough it out” should limit their intake. Continue reading...

items.title: Is Tylenol the same as paracetamol, and should you take it in pregnancy? Here’s why experts say Trump should be ignored
items.standfirst: The US president claims the painkiller also known as acetaminophen is linked to autism. Here’s what the science saysDonald Trump has urged pregnant women not to take acetaminophen, also known as Tylenol or paracetamol. He claimed it raises the chances of children being autistic.But the US president has been condemned by experts from across the world, who fear he is deliberately fostering a narrative of distrust that could be dangerous for women. Continue reading...
items.content: The US president claims the painkiller also known as acetaminophen is linked to autism. Here’s what the science saysDonald Trump has urged pregnant women not to take acetaminophen, also known as Tylenol or paracetamol. He claimed it raises the chances of children being autistic.But the US president has been condemned by experts from across the world, who fear he is deliberately fostering a narrative of distrust that could be dangerous for women. Continue reading...

items.title: Pregnant women deserve so much better than Trump’s theatre of scaremongering and shame | Kate Womersley
items.standfirst: There is no credible evidence linking autism with maternal paracetamol use. But the US president’s ‘tough it out’ message could harm mothers and babiesKate Womersley is a doctor and academic specialising in psychiatryOn Monday, Donald Trump, flanked by Robert F Kennedy Jr and the former talkshow host and head of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, Dr Mehmet Oz, announced that women should avoid paracetamol (known as acetaminophen or by the brand name Tylenol in the US) throughout pregnancy because of a spurious link with childhood autism.This political theatre highlights a longstanding and harmful problem: pregnant women, and their babies, are routinely let down by partial, poor-quality and missing medical evidence. Pregnant women deserve better than irresponsible headlines raising fear based on shaky research that has failed to convince the scientific community.Kate Womersley is a doctor and academic specialising in psychiatry Continue reading...
items.content: There is no credible evidence linking autism with maternal paracetamol use. But the US president’s ‘tough it out’ message could harm mothers and babiesKate Womersley is a doctor and academic specialising in psychiatryOn Monday, Donald Trump, flanked by Robert F Kennedy Jr and the former talkshow host and head of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, Dr Mehmet Oz, announced that women should avoid paracetamol (known as acetaminophen or by the brand name Tylenol in the US) throughout pregnancy because of a spurious link with childhood autism.This political theatre highlights a longstanding and harmful problem: pregnant women, and their babies, are routinely let down by partial, poor-quality and missing medical evidence. Pregnant women deserve better than irresponsible headlines raising fear based on shaky research that has failed to convince the scientific community.Kate Womersley is a doctor and academic specialising in psychiatry Continue reading...

items.title: Autism expert says Trump’s Tylenol claims ‘aren't based in fact’ – video
items.standfirst: Dr Audrey Brumback, an autism expert and researcher at the University of Texas at Austin, refutes Donald Trump's claims that acetaminophen, also known as Tylenol, is linked to autism. The advice from the US president, who has no medical training, goes against that of medical societies, which cite data from numerous studies showing acetaminophen plays a safe role in the wellbeing of pregnant womenTrump attacks Tylenol as officials unveil highly contentious conclusions on autismExperts alarmed as Trump pushes unproven link between Tylenol and autism Continue reading...
items.content: Dr Audrey Brumback, an autism expert and researcher at the University of Texas at Austin, refutes Donald Trump's claims that acetaminophen, also known as Tylenol, is linked to autism. The advice from the US president, who has no medical training, goes against that of medical societies, which cite data from numerous studies showing acetaminophen plays a safe role in the wellbeing of pregnant womenTrump attacks Tylenol as officials unveil highly contentious conclusions on autismExperts alarmed as Trump pushes unproven link between Tylenol and autism Continue reading...

ai_summary: Nigel Farage won't criticize Trump's claims about paracetamol.
Farage stated he has "no idea" if Trump is correct about the drug.
He said he would never "side with" medical experts on the issue.
Trump suggested pregnant women avoid acetaminophen, or Tylenol.
Farage believes "science is never settled" on the topic.

clusters.title: Fossil fuel burning poses threat to health of 1.6bn people, data shows
clusters.neutral_headline: Fossil fuel burning threatens health of 1.6 billion

items.title: Fossil fuel burning poses threat to health of 1.6bn people, data shows
items.standfirst: New interactive map tracking PM2.5 air pollution reveals 900m people in path of ‘super-emitting’ industrial facilitiesFossil fuel burning is not just damaging the world’s climate; it is also threatening the health of at least 1.6 billion people through the toxic pollutants it produces, data shows.Carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas from fossil fuel burning, does not directly damage health, but leads to global heating. However, coal and oil burning for power generation, and the burning of fossil fuels in industrial facilities, pollute the air with particulate matter called PM2.5, which has serious health impacts when breathed in. Continue reading...
items.content: New interactive map tracking PM2.5 air pollution reveals 900m people in path of ‘super-emitting’ industrial facilitiesFossil fuel burning is not just damaging the world’s climate; it is also threatening the health of at least 1.6 billion people through the toxic pollutants it produces, data shows.Carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas from fossil fuel burning, does not directly damage health, but leads to global heating. However, coal and oil burning for power generation, and the burning of fossil fuels in industrial facilities, pollute the air with particulate matter called PM2.5, which has serious health impacts when breathed in. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Fossil fuel burning endangers the health of 1.6 billion people.
The burning of fossil fuels releases toxic PM2.5 pollutants.
PM2.5 air pollution has serious health impacts when inhaled.
Carbon dioxide from fossil fuels contributes to global heating.
An interactive map tracks PM2.5 pollution from industrial facilities.

clusters.title: Better Days review – modest, honest study of woman trying to grapple with a drinking problem
clusters.neutral_headline: Review of "Better Days" focuses on drinking problem

items.title: Better Days review – modest, honest study of woman trying to grapple with a drinking problem
items.standfirst: Valérie Bonneton is terrific in French drama about women in rehab that gets a little carried awayThis French rehab drama begins with some painfully realistic scenes showing the grim slog of maintaining a hidden drinking problem. At night, after her kids go to bed, mum of three Suzanne (Valérie Bonneton) gets a box down from a high cupboard. Inside is her stash of vodka, which she carefully siphons into mineral water bottles for the next day. There is no pleasure in her drinking; it makes her foggy at work and detached from her boys. Bonneton, better known in France for comedy roles, is terrific, with her warm, worn performance, not a scrap of sentimentality in it.Suzanne hits her rock bottom after a car accident; the court puts her sons into the care of their grandparents and orders her into rehab. First comes denial. “Some wine with dinner,” she tells the doctor who asks her about her drinking at the all-female unit. Other residents include Diane (Michèle Laroque), a famous actor who haughtily lords it over the other women, and twentysomething Alice (Sabrina Ouazani), who describes herself as a party girl but whose stories, when she shares them in group, sound more self-destructive than fun. Continue reading...
items.content: Valérie Bonneton is terrific in French drama about women in rehab that gets a little carried awayThis French rehab drama begins with some painfully realistic scenes showing the grim slog of maintaining a hidden drinking problem. At night, after her kids go to bed, mum of three Suzanne (Valérie Bonneton) gets a box down from a high cupboard. Inside is her stash of vodka, which she carefully siphons into mineral water bottles for the next day. There is no pleasure in her drinking; it makes her foggy at work and detached from her boys. Bonneton, better known in France for comedy roles, is terrific, with her warm, worn performance, not a scrap of sentimentality in it.Suzanne hits her rock bottom after a car accident; the court puts her sons into the care of their grandparents and orders her into rehab. First comes denial. “Some wine with dinner,” she tells the doctor who asks her about her drinking at the all-female unit. Other residents include Diane (Michèle Laroque), a famous actor who haughtily lords it over the other women, and twentysomething Alice (Sabrina Ouazani), who describes herself as a party girl but whose stories, when she shares them in group, sound more self-destructive than fun. Continue reading...

ai_summary: "Better Days" is a French drama about a woman with a drinking problem.
The film shows the struggles of maintaining a hidden addiction.
Valérie Bonneton gives a strong performance in the lead role.
The film explores the woman's denial and eventual rehab.
Other characters include a famous actor and a young party girl.

clusters.title: Fears of new PFI-style ‘disaster’ as firms handed £6m to advise on using private funds for NHS clinics
clusters.neutral_headline: Firms hired to advise on private NHS clinics

items.title: Fears of new PFI-style ‘disaster’ as firms handed £6m to advise on using private funds for NHS clinics
items.standfirst: Exclusive: Consultants and lawyers hired to advise on using public-private partnerships to build ‘neighbourhood health centres’ in EnglandMinisters have handed firms £6m in contracts to help devise plans to build a network of new NHS clinics using private capital, despite fears the move could turn into a PFI-style disaster.The Department of Health and Social Care has awarded contracts worth £3m each to the management consultants Deloitte and the lawyers Addleshaw Goddard. They are advising the DHSC on whether to use public-private partnerships (PPPs) to help build dozens of the promised “neighbourhood health centres” in England. Continue reading...
items.content: Exclusive: Consultants and lawyers hired to advise on using public-private partnerships to build ‘neighbourhood health centres’ in EnglandMinisters have handed firms £6m in contracts to help devise plans to build a network of new NHS clinics using private capital, despite fears the move could turn into a PFI-style disaster.The Department of Health and Social Care has awarded contracts worth £3m each to the management consultants Deloitte and the lawyers Addleshaw Goddard. They are advising the DHSC on whether to use public-private partnerships (PPPs) to help build dozens of the promised “neighbourhood health centres” in England. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Firms are hired to advise on using private funds for NHS clinics.
The government awarded £6 million in contracts to consultants.
Deloitte and Addleshaw Goddard are the consulting firms involved.
The plan involves building "neighbourhood health centres" in England.
There are fears the project could become a PFI-style disaster.

clusters.title: Change prostate cancer treatment for black men to avoid ‘epidemic’, NHS urged
clusters.neutral_headline: NHS urged to change prostate cancer treatment

items.title: Change prostate cancer treatment for black men to avoid ‘epidemic’, NHS urged
items.standfirst: Campaigners seek to raise awareness that twice as many black men are getting the disease than white menThe NHS must change how black men are treated for prostate cancer to prevent “an epidemic of unnecessary deaths” in which twice as many die as white men, campaigners have warned.Academics are seeking to raise awareness that one in four black men are getting this cancer, twice the rate of white men, which is one in eight, according to Prostate Cancer UK’s analysis of patient datasets for England. One in 12 black men are at risk of dying of this condition compared with one in 24 white men. Continue reading...
items.content: Campaigners seek to raise awareness that twice as many black men are getting the disease than white menThe NHS must change how black men are treated for prostate cancer to prevent “an epidemic of unnecessary deaths” in which twice as many die as white men, campaigners have warned.Academics are seeking to raise awareness that one in four black men are getting this cancer, twice the rate of white men, which is one in eight, according to Prostate Cancer UK’s analysis of patient datasets for England. One in 12 black men are at risk of dying of this condition compared with one in 24 white men. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The NHS is urged to change prostate cancer treatment for black men.
Campaigners want to prevent an "epidemic" of unnecessary deaths.
Twice as many black men get prostate cancer compared to white men.
One in four black men are diagnosed with the disease.
One in 12 black men are at risk of dying from the condition.

clusters.title: ‘Children thrive down here’: the secret play centre hidden under Ukraine’s most dangerous city
clusters.neutral_headline: Play center hidden under Ukraine's city

items.title: ‘Children thrive down here’: the secret play centre hidden under Ukraine’s most dangerous city
items.standfirst: Kherson’s children have missed nearly four years of school, living in isolation or underground to hide from dronesIn an underground shelter in Kherson, probably the most dangerous city in Ukraine, children are chasing each other between plastic chairs. Outside,mortars, artillery and drones fly their deadly paths back and forth across the Dnipro River that separates the city from Russian forces.This makeshift underground play centre is one of the few places where children can socialise with each other in safety. For a few hours, it can be as though the war is not happening. When the explosions get too close, teachers working at the centre clap louder or turn up the music to drown out the noise. Continue reading...
items.content: Kherson’s children have missed nearly four years of school, living in isolation or underground to hide from dronesIn an underground shelter in Kherson, probably the most dangerous city in Ukraine, children are chasing each other between plastic chairs. Outside,mortars, artillery and drones fly their deadly paths back and forth across the Dnipro River that separates the city from Russian forces.This makeshift underground play centre is one of the few places where children can socialise with each other in safety. For a few hours, it can be as though the war is not happening. When the explosions get too close, teachers working at the centre clap louder or turn up the music to drown out the noise. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A play center operates in an underground shelter in Kherson, Ukraine.
Children in Kherson have missed nearly four years of school.
The center provides a safe space for children to socialize.
Mortars, artillery, and drones are active outside the shelter.
Teachers use music to drown out the sounds of explosions.

clusters.title: ‘Pay no attention’: global health agencies dismiss false Trump claim on everyday painkillers
clusters.neutral_headline: Global health agencies dismiss Trump's painkiller claim

items.title: ‘Pay no attention’: global health agencies dismiss false Trump claim on everyday painkillers
items.standfirst: Medical experts and regulators say US president should not be questioning established scienceGlobal health agencies and regulators have dismissed unscientific advice from Donald Trump that made an unproven link between autism and the use of everyday painkillers and vaccines.In a sign of how worried foreign governments are about the US president’s comments, the health secretary of the UK, which is one the US’s closest allies, told the British public they should not “pay any attention whatsoever to what Donald Trump says about medicine”. Continue reading...
items.content: Medical experts and regulators say US president should not be questioning established scienceGlobal health agencies and regulators have dismissed unscientific advice from Donald Trump that made an unproven link between autism and the use of everyday painkillers and vaccines.In a sign of how worried foreign governments are about the US president’s comments, the health secretary of the UK, which is one the US’s closest allies, told the British public they should not “pay any attention whatsoever to what Donald Trump says about medicine”. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Global health agencies dismiss Trump's claim on everyday painkillers.
Medical experts and regulators disagree with Trump's advice.
Trump made an unproven link between autism and painkillers.
The UK health secretary told the public to ignore Trump's claims.
Foreign governments are worried about Trump's comments.

clusters.title: Ed Davey warns NHS will be privatised and gun laws rolled back by ‘hypocrite’ Farage in Lib Dem conference speech – as it happened
clusters.neutral_headline: Ed Davey warns of NHS privatization by Farage

items.title: Ed Davey warns NHS will be privatised and gun laws rolled back by ‘hypocrite’ Farage in Lib Dem conference speech – as it happened
items.standfirst: This blog is now closed, you can read more on this story here:Lib Dems the last block against ‘forces of darkness’ led by Farage, says Ed DaveyEd Davey, the Lib Dem leader, criticised Donald Trump for “the cruelty and stupidity” of his approach to medical research in comments distributed yesterday before Trump made bogus claims about autism in the Oval Office. (See 8.41am.) Now Davey has described the president’s latest comments as “dangerous nonsense”.First Trump slashed funding for vaccines research now he’s peddling dangerous nonsense about paracetamol.The UK should take on Trump’s anti-science agenda and open our doors to US researchers.The US government is ignoring science and deliberately spreading misinformation. It will get people killed. And we have a Reform party that seems quite keen to import their health advice from these people.Boldest of the lot are the proposals on migration, which, if taken up even in part, would represent the biggest paradigm shift of all. Reform UK has set the agenda with proposals to deny benefits to even legal migrants. By the standards of the centre-left, Labour Together’s suggestion is just as radical.Rather than leave Isak, an Eritrean with post-traumatic stress disorder, languishing in an asylum hotel, their paper proposes he be granted time-limited refugee status for six months. He signs a contract that obliges him to learn English, find work and private accommodation; his access to any income support via universal credit is strictly conditional on him fulfilling its terms. Of all the changes suggested, this one – given that asylum seekers cannot currently work legally – would have the most profound consequences for British politics and the economy.Why an asylum-seeker is drawn to Britain over, say, France is not obvious. A 2016 report from Warwick University, based on findings from 29 separate studies into asylum-seeker motives, concluded that social networks and shared languages were crucial. The report could not find a single study showing a significant correlation between work rights and destination choice. If asylum-seekers in Calais were motivated by working rights those who had yet to apply would stay in France, where they could work sooner. Continue reading...
items.content: This blog is now closed, you can read more on this story here:Lib Dems the last block against ‘forces of darkness’ led by Farage, says Ed DaveyEd Davey, the Lib Dem leader, criticised Donald Trump for “the cruelty and stupidity” of his approach to medical research in comments distributed yesterday before Trump made bogus claims about autism in the Oval Office. (See 8.41am.) Now Davey has described the president’s latest comments as “dangerous nonsense”.First Trump slashed funding for vaccines research now he’s peddling dangerous nonsense about paracetamol.The UK should take on Trump’s anti-science agenda and open our doors to US researchers.The US government is ignoring science and deliberately spreading misinformation. It will get people killed. And we have a Reform party that seems quite keen to import their health advice from these people.Boldest of the lot are the proposals on migration, which, if taken up even in part, would represent the biggest paradigm shift of all. Reform UK has set the agenda with proposals to deny benefits to even legal migrants. By the standards of the centre-left, Labour Together’s suggestion is just as radical.Rather than leave Isak, an Eritrean with post-traumatic stress disorder, languishing in an asylum hotel, their paper proposes he be granted time-limited refugee status for six months. He signs a contract that obliges him to learn English, find work and private accommodation; his access to any income support via universal credit is strictly conditional on him fulfilling its terms. Of all the changes suggested, this one – given that asylum seekers cannot currently work legally – would have the most profound consequences for British politics and the economy.Why an asylum-seeker is drawn to Britain over, say, France is not obvious. A 2016 report from Warwick University, based on findings from 29 separate studies into asylum-seeker motives, concluded that social networks and shared languages were crucial. The report could not find a single study showing a significant correlation between work rights and destination choice. If asylum-seekers in Calais were motivated by working rights those who had yet to apply would stay in France, where they could work sooner. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Ed Davey warns of NHS privatization and gun law rollbacks.

clusters.title: The tragedy of a second runway at Gatwick | Brief letters
clusters.neutral_headline: The tragedy of a second runway at Gatwick | Brief letters

items.title: The tragedy of a second runway at Gatwick | Brief letters
items.standfirst: Climate agreements | Donald Trump’s meds | Pass the duchess | Your Party woes | Get well soonGatwick’s second runway is yet another example of the tragedy of the commons (Gatwick given green light for £2.2bn second runway plan, 21 September). While all nations benefit from a healthy climate, each also benefits from actions which damage the climate. Only international cooperation – including a binding agreement to phase out fossil fuel production – can prevent this tragedy.Dr Andrew BodeyOxford• It would be far more helpful, to the widest possible number of people, if Donald Trump were to disclose what he is taking (Trump attacks Tylenol as officials unveil highly contentious conclusions on autism, 22 September). Then we could all avoid it.Neil BlackshawAlnwick, Northumberland Continue reading...

While all nations benefit from a healthy climate, each also benefits from actions which damage the climate. Only international cooperation – including a binding agreement to phase out fossil fuel production – can prevent this tragedy.Dr Andrew BodeyOxford• It would be far more helpful, to the widest possible number of people, if Donald Trump were to disclose what he is taking (Trump attacks Tylenol as officials unveil highly contentious conclusions on autism, 22 September). Then we could all avoid it.Neil BlackshawAlnwick, Northumberland Continue reading...

items.content: The mission around the Moon will pave the way for a lunar landing as soon as 2027.

ai_summary: NASA plans a crewed mission around the Moon, setting the stage for a lunar landing.
The lunar landing is targeted for as early as the year 2027, according to NASA's plans.
This mission marks the first crewed Moon mission in five decades for the space agency.
The mission is scheduled for February 2026, according to the BBC Science report.
The mission will be a crucial step in NASA's Artemis program.

clusters.title: ‘Tentacles squelching wetly’: the human subtitle writers under threat from AI
clusters.neutral_headline: ‘Tentacles squelching wetly’: the human subtitle writers under threat from AI

items.title: ‘Tentacles squelching wetly’: the human subtitle writers under threat from AI
items.standfirst: Artificial intelligence is making steady advances into subtitling but, say its practitioners, it’s a vital service that needs a human to make it workIs artificial intelligence going to destroy the SDH [subtitles for the deaf and hard of hearing] industry? It’s a valid question because, while SDH is the default subtitle format on most platforms, the humans behind it – as with all creative industries – are being increasingly devalued in the age of AI. “SDH is an art, and people in the industry have no idea. They think it’s just a transcription,” says Max Deryagin, chair of Subtle, a non-profit association of freelance subtitlers and translators.The thinking is that AI should simplify the process of creating subtitles, but that is way off the mark, says Subtle committee member Meredith Cannella. “There’s an assumption that we now have to do less work because of AI tools. But I’ve been doing this now for about 14-15 years, and there hasn’t been much of a difference in how long it takes me to complete projects over the last five or six years.” Continue reading...
items.content: Artificial intelligence is making steady advances into subtitling but, say its practitioners, it’s a vital service that needs a human to make it workIs artificial intelligence going to destroy the SDH [subtitles for the deaf and hard of hearing] industry? It’s a valid question because, while SDH is the default subtitle format on most platforms, the humans behind it – as with all creative industries – are being increasingly devalued in the age of AI. “SDH is an art, and people in the industry have no idea. They think it’s just a transcription,” says Max Deryagin, chair of Subtle, a non-profit association of freelance subtitlers and translators.The thinking is that AI should simplify the process of creating subtitles, but that is way off the mark, says Subtle committee member Meredith Cannella. “There’s an assumption that we now have to do less work because of AI tools. But I’ve been doing this now for about 14-15 years, and there hasn’t been much of a difference in how long it takes me to complete projects over the last five or six years.” Continue reading...

ai_summary: Artificial intelligence is making advances in subtitling, but human input remains vital.
SDH (subtitles for the deaf and hard of hearing) is the default format on most platforms.
Human subtitlers feel increasingly devalued in the creative industries due to AI.
Max Deryagin, chair of Subtle, says SDH is an art, not just transcription.
Meredith Cannella notes AI tools haven't significantly reduced project completion times.

clusters.title: Trump’s absurd Tylenol claims heighten the suffering of pregnant women in the US | Moira Donegan
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump’s absurd Tylenol claims heighten the suffering of pregnant women in the US | Moira Donegan

items.title: Trump’s absurd Tylenol claims heighten the suffering of pregnant women in the US | Moira Donegan
items.standfirst: There is no evidence to support the president’s assertions about autism. But they exploit fears that already come with pregnancyRobert F Kennedy Jr continued his futile search for a single pharmaceutical cause of autism on Monday, when the Trump administration claimed that distorted recent studies and misstated scientific evidence to allege a link between women’s Tylenol use during pregnancy and the development of autism in children. Kennedy has long spoken with disturbing disgust about autistic people, claiming at one press conference that autistic children “destroy families” and “will never pay taxes. They’ll never hold a job. They’ll never play baseball. They’ll never write a poem. They’ll never go out on a date.” He had previously pledged to find the cause of autism by this month.As part of his apparent quest to eliminate this vast and varied group of people – who do, in fact, pay taxes, hold jobs, play baseball, write poems, go on dates, and function as beloved and caring members of functional families – Kennedy has already sought to restrict access to common vaccines. In June, he fired every member of the advisory committee on immunization practices, an influential group of vaccine experts whose recommendations had long shaped policy for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. In place of the experts, he reconstituted the panel with a number of vaccine critics and cranks, whose incompetence has led to chaotic meetings and bizarrely changing vaccine recommendations. Donald Trump has recently joined his health secretary in casting aspersions on childhood vaccines – safe and effective treatments that have saved countless lives and are among the more wonderful miracles of human innovation. “It’s too much liquid,” the president said of the early childhood immunizations on Monday. “Too many different things are going into that baby at too big a number. The size of this thing, when you look at it.” Continue reading...
items.content: There is no evidence to support the president’s assertions about autism. But they exploit fears that already come with pregnancyRobert F Kennedy Jr continued his futile search for a single pharmaceutical cause of autism on Monday, when the Trump administration claimed that distorted recent studies and misstated scientific evidence to allege a link between women’s Tylenol use during pregnancy and the development of autism in children. Kennedy has long spoken with disturbing disgust about autistic people, claiming at one press conference that autistic children “destroy families” and “will never pay taxes. They’ll never hold a job. They’ll never play baseball. They’ll never write a poem. They’ll never go out on a date.” He had previously pledged to find the cause of autism by this month.As part of his apparent quest to eliminate this vast and varied group of people – who do, in fact, pay taxes, hold jobs, play baseball, write poems, go on dates, and function as beloved and caring members of functional families – Kennedy has already sought to restrict access to common vaccines. In June, he fired every member of the advisory committee on immunization practices, an influential group of vaccine experts whose recommendations had long shaped policy for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. In place of the experts, he reconstituted the panel with a number of vaccine critics and cranks, whose incompetence has led to chaotic meetings and bizarrely changing vaccine recommendations. Donald Trump has recently joined his health secretary in casting aspersions on childhood vaccines – safe and effective treatments that have saved countless lives and are among the more wonderful miracles of human innovation. “It’s too much liquid,” the president said of the early childhood immunizations on Monday. “Too many different things are going into that baby at too big a number. The size of this thing, when you look at it.” Continue reading...

ai_summary: Trump's claims about Tylenol and autism lack supporting evidence, exploiting pregnancy fears.
Robert F. Kennedy Jr. continues his search for a pharmaceutical cause of autism.
Kennedy has made disparaging remarks about autistic people and their families.
Kennedy sought to restrict access to common vaccines, replacing experts with critics.
Trump has also cast aspersions on childhood vaccines, citing concerns about liquid volume.

clusters.title: ‘Families are dying’: an Ohio town suffering from fallout years after nuclear plant’s closure
clusters.neutral_headline: ‘Families are dying’: an Ohio town suffering from fallout years after nuclear plant’s closure

items.title: ‘Families are dying’: an Ohio town suffering from fallout years after nuclear plant’s closure
items.standfirst: As Trump calls for more nuclear power, Piketon, the site of an enrichment facility, knows first hand its ill effectsThree years after starting work as an electrician at the Portsmouth Gaseous Diffusion Plant, Vina Colley started getting sick.The huge facility in the foothills of Appalachian Ohio was opened in 1954 to enrich weapons-grade uranium for the military as America’s cold war with the Soviet Union ramped up, and later, for commercial purposes. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

ai_summary: Piketon, Ohio, is experiencing the negative effects of a nuclear plant's closure.
The town was the site of a uranium enrichment facility.
Vina Colley, an electrician, became ill after working at the plant.
The Portsmouth Gaseous Diffusion Plant opened in 1954 for military uranium enrichment.
The plant later enriched uranium for commercial purposes.
